column1: Osorno city and commune in southern Chile and capital of Osorno Province in the Los Lagos Region. It had a population of 145
column3: as of the 2002 census. It is located 945 kilometres (587 mi) south of the national capital of Santiago
column4: 105 kilometres (65 mi) north of the regional capital of Puerto Montt and 260 kilometres (160 mi) west of the Argentine city of San Carlos de Bariloche
column5: connected via International Route 215 through the Cardenal Antonio Samoré Pass. It is a gateway for land access to the remote southern regions of Aysén and Magallanes
column6: which would otherwise be accessible only by sea from the rest of the country.

column1: Located at the confluence of Rahue and Damas River Osorno is the main service centre of agriculture and cattle farming in the northern Los Lagos Region. The city's cultural heritage is shaped by Spanish
column2: Huilliche and German influences.

column1: The city of Osorno is built upon river terraces formed during the last of Earth's geological periods —the Quaternary. 130
column2: 000 years ago
column3: during the transition from the Santa María glaciation and the Valdivia interglacial the area of Osorno was covered by pyroclastic material derivative from large and explosive volcanic eruptions in the Andes. The substrate of Osorno is accordingly made of various combinations of volcanic ash
column4: lapilli
column5: sand and gravel with occasional layers of peat. The city hosts the site of Pilauco Bajo
column6: a paleontological and archaeological site with an adjoining museum.

column1: The city was originally planned to be founded in 1553
column2: under the Government of Pedro de Valdivia by his companion of conquest
column3: Lieutenant General Don Francisco de Villagra; with the name of Santa Marina de Gaete
column4: on the site of a Huilliche village named Chauracavi. However
column5: Valdivia's death prevented the realization of this plan before it could materialize.

column2: the city was finally founded by governor García Hurtado de Mendoza
column3: with the new name of Villa de San Mateo de Osorno
column4: in honor of his grandfather
column5: Count of Osorno. It was destroyed again by the indigenous Huilliche people in October 1602. The destruction of Osorno forced Spaniards and the remaining indigenous allies to migrate south to the vacinities of Chilé Archipelago where Spanish rule was still upheld. Indigenous allies the followed the Spanish on their departure were declared indios reyunos and became free of encomienda and held the duty to form a militia. The indios reyunos settled chiefly in Calbuco and Abtao. Fernando de Alvarado
column7: led the Spanish resistance in Chiloé against Dutch invaders in 1643.The plains of Osorno and the whole area between Valdivia and the settlements of Calbuco and Carelmapu remained independent indigenous territory closed to the Spanish. The Spanish had thus little information on this territory and had to rely on hearsay. This lack of concrete knowledge of the territory fueled speculations about the mythical City of the Caesars.

column2: Tomás de Figueroa took possession of the ruins. Under the orders of Ambrosio O'Higgins
column3: Osorno was again rebuilt by Juan Mackenna
column4: and declared officially re-populated in 1796. O'Higgins
column6: was awarded the title of Marquess of Osorno.

column1: Osorno owes its legacy to fairly recent Chilean settlement
column2: when the government subdued the region's indigenous Mapuche peoples in the mid-19th century and opened the land to Chilean and European immigration soon to follow. Large percentage of locals in Osorno are descendants of Spanish (the livestock grazing industry owes its foundation to the Basques) and other European immigrants.

the government of Chile began inviting German settlers to the colony to promote growth in the region; the settlers found Osorno's climate and geography to be very similar to their own. With their help
column3: Osorno was made the home of the National Cattle ranch of Chile
column4: boosting the regional economy significantly. Present-day Osorno has preserved 19th century architecture and urban layout
column5: represented by six picturesque houses which have been designated national monuments.Osorno has a long history of rivalry with Valdivia
column7: the Osorno Province rejected its proposed incorporation into the new Los Ríos Region
column8: of which Valdivia is now the capital.

column1: Osorno has an oceanic climate (Köppen climate classification Cfb) with a drying trend in summer. Winters are cool but mild with a July average of 7.6 °C (45.7 °F). Most of the precipitation falls during this time of the year with May to July being the wettest months
column2: averaging around 180 millimetres (7 in) to 210 millimetres (8 in) of precipitation and humidity is high
column3: averaging around 85%. Snowfalls are rare. Summers are drier and mild with a January average of 17.8 °C (64.0 °F) and during this time
column4: precipitation is lower
column5: averaging 48.9 millimetres (2 in) in January. In some years
column6: many days can go without a day of precipitation such as the case in 1992 when only 1.1 millimetres (0 in) of precipitation was recorded in January while in other years
column7: some summers can have several wet days in a row. Temperatures can occasionally exceed 25 °C (77 °F) anytime from December to March. The average annual precipitation is 1
column8: 318 millimetres (52 in) and there are 173 days with measureable precipitation. The record high was 36.5 °C (97.7 °F) in February 2019  and the record low was −8.0 °C (17.6 °F) in July 1954.

column1: Osorno sits in sight of Volcán Osorno
column2: an active but minor volcano. The city's most prominent geographical feature is the Rahue River that runs north-south through its center. A smaller stream breaks off as well
column3: running east before turning south and giving the city some natural boundaries. Located near the river front on the east side is the city's heart
column4: the Plaza de Armas
column8: and tree-lined avenues. On the park's east side is La Catedral of Saint Matthew
column9: one of the city's major landmarks
column10: notable for its modern architecture. The cathedral serves as mother church of the Catholic Diocese of Osorno. Along the south side is Juan Mackenna Avenue
column11: the city's major city centre street. Other points of interest are the main campus of the Universidad de Los Lagos and the Osorno Rodeo Stadium.  The recently opened casino Plaza Sol de los Lagos is a new popular attraction for tourists and locals alike.

column1: Osorno hosts a number of annual celebrations. The Festival de la Carne y la Leche (Milk and Meat Festival) is a music festival held annually in late January
column2: features performances by national music pop singers and bands. The Festival del Folklore Campesino (Country Folk Festival) held annually in mid-January
column3: features performances of regional music folk artists.

column1: Another celebration is the Feria Ganadera Sago Fisur (Sago-Fisur Cattle Fair) held annually in early November
column2: hosted by the largest ranch in the area highlights the current state of agricultural activity. Fireworks displays are held every year around the city on 18 September
column3: the Chilean national Day
column4: commemorating independence from Spain.

column1: Osorno is also a gateway for many tourist attractions. Puyehue National Park is a major attraction
column2: with pristine lakes
column3: forests
column4: and game preserves. The volcanic area provides natural hot springs
column5: now the site of the Aguas Calientes spa. Puyehue Hot Springs is adjacent to the park.

column1: Los Lagos Region was named for the many lakes in the area
column2: many of which have tourist-friendly yet isolated beaches; closest to Osorno are Puyehue and Rupanco.Antillanca ski resort
column3: less than a hundred kilometers away
column4: is one of the highest-quality resorts in Chile. Ecotourism is also encouraged by the indigenous Huilliche communities
column5: who inhabit the Pacific coastal zone. Much of the funds brought in by tourism is being used to protect native plant and tree species
column7: a threatened Cypress. The thick forests open onto a number of beaches and bays

column1: Chilean rodeo is popular in Osorno
column2: as it is in most of the center-south zone of the country. Osorno's rodeo stadium
column3: the Medialuna de Osorno
column4: is considered one of the bests in the country
column5: and was the qualifying arena for the southern region of the national rodeo in 2006.

column1: Boxing is also one of the city's pastimes; Osorno produced Chile's boxing representative at the 1972 Summer Olympics
column2: Martín Vargas. Additionally
column3: the mountainous terrain surrounding Osorno is used for skiing and snowboarding
column4: sports popularized by the large tide of German immigrants. It is the closest city to the Antillanca ski resort

column1: Osorno is an important agricultural center
column2: and agriculture makes up the bulk of the Osorno province's economic activity. Wheat and oats grow abundantly
column3: but the land is also well-suited to the breeding of Chilean horses and cattle. Some of Chile's finest beef products originate in the Osorno ranches.

column1: Osorno's proximity to the Cardenal Antonio Samoré Pass makes it a key place the national economy. The mountain pass connects Osorno to the Argentine city of Bariloche
column2: and is one of primary arteries that ties the two countries' southern regions together. The pass is particularly important due to the fact that it crosses the Andes mountains at very low altitude
column3: allowing it to remain open even when other passes are blocked by snow.

column2: Osorno has seen some economic stagnation in the past several decades. Agriculture alone has not allowed it to keep pace with the booming
column3: rapidly industrializing Chilean economy; Osorno lacks both industrial and information-services sectors. In one effort to combat this
column4: the city has forged international business ties with several Dutch companies
column5: after it was discovered that the local climate is ideal for the growing of tulips. Likewise
column6: Osorno has recently entered the international meat market. Besides offering high-quality beef
column7: the isolated region is also completely free of the recent rash of cattle plagues such as Mad Cow and foot-and-mouth disease
column8: guaranteeing the safety of Chilean meats.

column1: Osorno is now faced with a unique opportunity: the arable land is suited for the growing of beets
column2: soy
column3: and corn
column4: crops rising in popularity with the recent development of biocombustibles: fuels derived from crops
column5: such as corn-derived ethanol. It is hoped that the Chilean government's announcement that it will not apply the same steep taxes to agricultural fuels as it does to petroleum products
column6: as well as the increasing demand for more environment-friendly fuels
column7: will mean that Osorno will again become a major economic hub.

column1: As Chile continues to develop as one of South America's economic leaders and one of the most stable states in the region
column2: tourism is on the rise
column3: and visitors are attracted by Osorno's natural environment and old-European atmosphere.

column1: The city is served by Canal Bajo Carlos Hott Siebert Airport
column2: which offers 2-hour flights to Santiago. Buses also depart for the capital daily. The Cardenal Antonio Samoré Pass also marks the city as a major gateway to and from Argentina.

Osorno is a third-level administrative division of Chile administered by a municipal council
column3: headed by an alcalde who is directly elected every four years. The 2008-2012 alcalde is Jaime Alberto Bertin Valenzuela.Within the electoral divisions of Chile
column4: Osorno is represented in the Chamber of Deputies by Fidel Espinoza (PS)
column6: Harry Jürgensen (RN) and Emilia Nuyado (PS) as part of the 25th electoral district. The commune is represented in the Senate by Rabindranath Quinteros Lara (PS) and Iván Alejandro Moreira Barros (UDI) as part of the 17th senatorial constituency (Los Lagos Region).
